Introduction

What is probability?

  • Frequentists says,

    Probabilities are frequencies of events that can happen multiple times.

  • Whereas Bayesians says,

    Probability is used to quantify our uncertainty or ignorance about something, which can also be one-off events.

Types of Uncertainty

Epistemic uncertainty or model uncertainty is due to our ignorance of the underlying hidden causes or mechanism generating our data; while aleatoric uncertainty or data uncertainty is the intrinsic variability of data.

Probability as an Extension of Logic

An event can be denoted by a Boolean variable A, the expression Pr(A) denotes the probability that A is true, where

(1)0≤Pr(A)≤1,
(2)Pr(A¯)=1−Pr(A).

The joint probability is defined as

(3)Pr(A,B)≜Pr(A∧B).

If A and B are independent,

(4)Pr(A,B)=Pr(A)Pr(B).

The probability of a union of two events is defined as

(5)Pr(A∨B)≜Pr(A)+Pr(B)−Pr(A,B).

If A and B are mutually exclusive, then

(6)Pr(A∨B)=Pr(A)+Pr(B).

Conditional Probability

The conditional probability of event B happening given that A has occurred is defined as:

(7)Pr(B|A)≜Pr(A,B)Pr(A).

A is unconditionally independent of event B if Pr(A,B)=Pr(A)(B), denoted by A⊥B; given event C, A is conditionally independent of B if Pr(A,B|C)=Pr(A|C)Pr(B|C), denoted by A⊥B|C. We can show that events that are dependent on each other may be independent on some conditions.

Random Variables

Definition

If the value of X is unknown and/or could change, it is called a random variable (RV). The set of possible values of X is called the sample space or state space, denoted by X.

Discrete Random Variables

If X is finite or countably infinite, then X is called a discrete random variable. The probability of the event that X has the value x is denoted by Pr(X=x).

The probability mass function (PMF) is the function of x which computes the probability of events corresponding to setting the RV to each possible value:

(8)pX(x)≜Pr(X=x).

The PMF satisfies the properties that 0≤pX(x)≤1 and ∑x∈XpX(x)=1.

Continuous Random Variables

If X∈R, it is called a continuous random variable. In this case Pr(X=x)→0, so we can only talk about the probability that X has the value in a specific range.

 

Cumulative Distribution Function (CDF)

The cumulative distribution function (CDF) of an RV X is defined as

(9)PX(x)≜Pr(X≤x).

With the definition, we have

(10)Pr(a<X≤b)=PX(b)−PX(a).

CDF's are always monotonically non-decreasing functions.

 

Probability Density Function (PDF)

The probability density function (PDF) of an RV is defined as the derivative of the CDF:

(11)pX(x)≜ddxPX(x).

Similarly, given the PDF, we can calculate

(12)Pr(a<X≤b)=∫abp(x)dx.

As the size of the interval gets smaller, we have the following property:

(13)Pr(x<X≤x+dx)=p(x)dx.

Quantiles

If the CDF P is strictly monotonically increasing, it has an inverse called the inverse cdf or percent point function (PPF), or quantile function.

If P is the CDF of X, P−1(q) is the value xq such that Pr(X≤xq)=q. xq is called the q-th quantile of P. The following table lists some important quantiles:

Sets of Related Random Variables

Joint Distribution

The joint distribution of X and Y is defined as

(14)p(x,y)≜p(X=x,Y=y).

Marginal Distribution

The marginal distribution of X given the joint distribution of X and Y is

(15)p(X=x)=∑yp(X=x,Y=y).

Conditional Distribution

The conditional distribution of X given Y is

(16)pX|Y(x|y)≜p(X=x|Y=y)=p(x,y)p(y).

From Equation 16 we get the product rule:

(17)p(x,y)=p(x|y)p(y).

Moreover, we have the chain rule of probability:

(18)p(x1:D)=p(x1)p(x2|x1)p(x3|x1,x2)⋯p(xD|x1:D−1).

Independence and Conditional Independence

We say that X and Y are unconditionally independent or marginally independent if we can represent the joint as the product of two marginals:

(19)X⊥Y⇔p(x,y)=p(x)p(y).

For a set of variables {X1,⋯,Xn}, they are mutually independent, if ∀ {Xi,⋯,Xj}⊆{X1,⋯,Xn}, the joint can be written as a product of marginals:

(20)p(xi,⋯,xj)=∏k=ijp(xk).

We say thay X and Y are conditionally independent given Z iff. the conditional joint can be written as a product of conditional marginals:

(21)X⊥Y|Z⇔p(x,y|z)=p(x|z)p(y|z).

Moments of a Distribution

Mean or Expectation

The mean or the expectation of a discrete RV, denoted by μ, is defined as

(22)E[X] ≜∑x∈Xxp(x).

For continuous RV's, it is defined as

(23)E[X]≜∫Xxp(x)dx.

If the integral is not finite, the mean is not defined.

Here are some properties of the mean:

Linearity of the mean:

(24)E[aX+b]=aE[X]+b.
(25)E[∑i=1nXi]=∑i=1nE[Xi].

If X1,⋯,Xn are mutually independent,

(26)E[∏i=1nXi]=∏i=1nE[Xi].

Variance

The variance of an RV, denoted by σ2, is defined as

(27)V[X]≜E[(X−μ)2]=E[X2]−μ2.

From Equation 27 we have

(28)E[X2]=σ2+μ2.

The standard deviation is defined as

(29)std[X]≜V[X]=σ,

which has the same unit as X.

Properties of the variance:

(30)V[aX+b]=a2V[X].

For independent RV's,

(31)V[∑i=1nXi]=∑i=1nV[Xi];

and

(32)V[∏i=1nXi]=∏i=1n(σi2+μi2)−∏i=1nμi2.

Mode

The mode of a distribution is the value with the highest probability mass or probability density:

(33)mode[X]=x∗≜argmaxxp(x).

Conditional Moments

When we have two or more dependent RV's, we can compute the moments of one given knowledge of the other.

The law of total expectation:

(34)E[X]=EY[E[X|Y]].

The law of total variance:

(35)V[X]=EY[V[X|Y]]+VY[E[X|Y]].

Limitations of Summary Statistics

Different distributions may have the same summary statistics.

 

Bayes' Rule

Bayes' Rule

Bayes' rule is a formula for updating the distribution of an unknown quantity H given some observation Y:

(36)p(H=h|Y=y)=p(H=h)p(Y=y|H=h)p(Y=y).

p(H) represents what we know about possible values of H before we see any data, which is called prior distribution. p(Y|H=h) represents the distribution over the possible value Y we expect to see if H=h, which is called observation distribution. When we evaluate this at a point corresponding to the actual observations, y, the observation distribution is a function of h, which is also called the likelihood. p(Y=y) is the marginal likelihood, as it is computed by marginalizing over the unknown H:

(37)p(Y=y)=∑h′∈Hp(H=h′)p(Y=y|H=h′)=∑h′∈Hp(H=h′,Y=y).

Normalizing the joint distribution by dividing by the marginal likelihood gives the posterior distribution p(H=h|Y=y).

Bayes' rule can be summarized as:

(38)posterior=prior×likelihoodmarginal likelihood∝prior×likelihood.

Using Bayes' rule to update a distribution over unknown values of some quantity of interest, given relevant observed data, is called Bayesian inference or posterior inference.

Example: Testing for COVID-19

Let H=1 be the event of being infected COVID-19, and H=0 be the event of being not infected. Let Y=1 be the event that the test result is positive, and Y=0 be the event that the test result is negative. We have the following quantities of measuring the reliability of the test:

If the overall prevalence is 10%, the sensitivity and the specificity of the test is 87.5% and 97.5%, respectively. If you test positive, the probability that you are infected is:

(39)p(H=1|Y=1)=prevalence×sensitivityprevalence×sensitivity+(1−prevalence)×(1−specificy)=0.795.

It tells us that there is still a 20.5% chance of being not infected.

If the prevalence reduces to 0.01, the chance of being not infected raises to ~26%.

Example: The Monty Hall Problem

In a game show, there are three doors, labeled 1, 2, and 3. A single prize has been hidden behind one of them. You get to select one door. Then the gameshow host opens one of the other doors in such a way as not to reveal the prize location. At this point, you will be given a fresh choice of door, you can either stick with your first choice, or you can switch to the other closed door. All the doors will then be opened and you will receive whatever is behind your final choice of door.

The Monty Hall problem is, whether switching to another door makes difference or not?

Assume you choose door 1, and the gameshow host opens door 3, revealing nothing behind the door. Let P(H) be the probability that the prize is behind the H-th door. Then we have

(40)P(H=1)=P(H=2)=P(H=3)=13.

Let P(Y) be the probability that the gameshow host opens the Y-th door.

Then

(41)P(H=1|Y=3):P(H=2|Y=3):P(H=3|Y=3)= P(Y=3|H=1)P(H=1):P(Y=3|H=2)P(H=2):P(Y=3|H=3)P(H=3)= 1/2:1:0= 1:2:0

Therefore, it is better to switch the door.

Inverse Problems

Inverse probability is concerned with inferring the state of the world from observations of outcomes. Inferring a 3d shape from a 2d image is a classic problem in visual scene understanding, which is an ill-posed problem. To tackle such inverse problems, we can use Bayes' rule to compute the posterior.

 

Bernoulli and Binomial Distributions

Definitions

If there are two states of the event Y, and the probability is given 0≤θ≤1. Thus p(Y=1)=θ,p(Y=0)=1−θ. Then Y satisfies the Bernoulli distribution, denoted by Y∼Ber(θ). The PMF of Bernoulli distribution is defined as:

(42)Ber(y|θ)={1−θif y=0θif y=1=θy(1−θ)1−y.

If we have N Bernoulli trials, let s be the total number of y=1, s≜∑n=1NI(yn=1). Then s follows the binomial distribution, denoted by s∼Bin(N,θ). The PMF is defined as:

(43)Bin(s|N,θ)≜(Ns)θs(i−θ)N−s,

where

(44)(Ns)≜N!s!(N−s)!

are called binomial coefficients. If N=1, the binomial distribution reduces to the Bernoulli distribution.

Sigmoid (Logistic) Function

When we want to predict a binary variable y∈{0,1} given some inputs x∈X, we need to use a conditional probability distribution having the form

(45)p(y|x,θ)=Ber(y|f(x;θ)),

where f(x;θ) is some function that predicts the mean parameter of the output distribution. There will be many different kinds of f.

To avoid the requirement that 0≤f(x;θ)≤1, we can let f be an unconstrained function and use the following model:

(46)p(y|x,θ)=Ber(y|σ(f(x;θ))),

where σ is called the sigmoid or logistic function, defined as

(47)σ(a)≜11+e−a,

where a=f(x;θ) is called the logit,

(48)a=logit(p)=σ−1(p)=log⁡(p1−p).

The sigmoid function is a map from R→(0,1). It can be thought as a soft version of the Heaviside step function, defined by

(49)H(a)≜I(a>0).

Illustration of the sigmoid function (left) and the Heaviside step function (right)

Here are some useful properties of the sigmoid function:

(50)ddxσ(x)=σ(x)(1−σ(x));
(51)1−σ(x)=σ(−x);
(52)softplus(x)≜σ+(x)≜log⁡(1+ex);
(53)ddxσ+(x)=σ(x).

Binary Logistic Regression

In binary logistic regression, f(x;θ)=w⊤x+b. The model has the form:

(54)p(y=1|x;θ)=σ(w⊤x+b)=11+e−(w⊤x+b).

The decision boundary is the value x∗ where p(y=1|x=x∗,θ)=0.5.

 

Categorical and Multinomial Distributions

Definitions

The categorical distribution is a discrete probability with one parameter per class θ=[θ1,⋯,θC],

(55)Cat(y|θ)≜∏c=1CθcI(y=c).

Equivalently,

(56)p(y=c|θ)=θc,

where θc must satisfies the constraint that 0≤θc≤1 and ∑c=1Cθc=1.

We can also encode the discrete variable y into a one-hot vector y=[y1,y2,⋯,yC], where yc=I(y=c). Then

(57)Cat(y|θ)≜∏c=1Cθcyc.

Observing N categorical trials, the number of occurrences of different class s follows multinomial distribution, denoted by s∼M(N,θ), where sc≜∑n=1NI(yn=c) . Multinomial distribution is defined as:

(58)M(s|N,θ)≜(Ns1⋯sC)∏c=1Cθcsc,

where θc is the probability that the class c shows up, and (Ns1⋯sC)≜N!s1!⋯sc!. If N=1, it becomes categorical distribution.

Softmax Function

In the conditional case of the categorical distribution, we have

(59)p(y|x,θ)=Cat(y|f(x;θ)).

To avoid the constraint that f directly predict a probability vector, it is common to pass the output from f into the softmax function or multinomial logit, which is defined as:

(60)S(a)≜[E(a1)∑c′=1CE(ac′),⋯,E(aC)∑c′=1CE(ac′)].

The softmax function maps RC→[0,1]C. The inputs to the softmax function a=f(x;θ) are called logits.

Divide each ac by a constant T called the temperature. As T→0, we find:

(61)S(a/T)c={1.0if c=argmaxc′ac′0.0otherwise.

At low temperatures, the distribution puts most of its probability mass in the most probable state, which is called winner takes all. Whereas at high temperatures, the distribution becomes uniform distribution.


Illustration of the effect of temperature

Multiclass Logistic Regression

If we use a linear predictor of the form f(x;θ)=Wx+b, where W is a C×D matrix, and b is a C-dimensional bias vector, the final model becomes

(62)p(y|x;b)=Cat(y|S(Wx+b)).

Let a=Wx+b be the C-dimensional vector of logits. Then

(63)p(y|x;θ)=eac∑c′=1Ceac.

This is known as multinomial logistic regression.

If there are only two classes, this reduces to binary logistic regression:

(64)S(a)0=ea0ea0+ea1=11+ea1−a0=σ(a0−a1).

The prediction can be down with a single weight vector w. If we use the multi-class formulation, we will have two weight vectors w0 and w1. Such a model is over-parameterized.

Log-Sum-Exp Trick

When calculating the softmax probability, we have the form

(65)pc=eacZ(a),

where Z is called the partition function. However, if a are too large, Z(a) will cause +inf on computers. Similarly, if a are too small, Z(a) will cause NaN on computers. To avoid such problem, we can use the following identity:

(66)log⁡∑c=1CE(ac)=m+log⁡∑c=1CE(ac−m).

It is common to use m=maxcac. This is known as the log-sum-exp trick. We use this trick when implementing the LSE function:

(67)LSE(a)≜log⁡∑c=1CE(ac).

When computing the probabilities from logits, we can use the LSE function:

(68)p(y=c|x)=E(ac−LSE(a)).

To save computational effort and for numerical stability, it is quite common to modify the cross-entropy loss so that it takes the logits a as inputs, instead of the probability vector p. Considering the binary case, the CE loss for one example is

(69)L=−[I(y=0)log⁡p0+I(y=1)log⁡p1],

where

(70)log⁡p1=log⁡(11+E(−a))=log⁡(1)−log⁡(1+E(−a))=−LSE([0,−a]),
(71)log⁡p0=−LSE([0,+a]).
